SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Vertebrobasilar nonsaccular intracranial aneurysms (VBNIA) are characterized by dilatation, elongation, and tortuosity of the vertebrobasilar system
METHODS: The medical records and imaging of patients with vertebrobasilar fusiform aneurysms or dolichoectasia between 1989 and 2001 were reviewed
RESULTS: One hundred and fifty-nine patients were identified (74% male) with 719 patient years of follow-up
Presenting events included: hemorrhage (3%), ischemia (28%), and compression (22%)
The 1-, 5-, and 10-year risk of cerebral infarction (CI) due toVBNIA is 2.7, 11.3, and 15.9% respectively
The risk of recurrent CI is 6.7% per patient year
Median survival was 7.8 years and death was most commonly due to ischemia
CONCLUSIONS: VBNIA are more common in men and typically present in the 6-7th decade
Recurrent CI is more common than hemorrhage risk
